question: Question_06
statement:
At a certain time, the stock of a company listed on the Vancouver Stock
Exchange is selling for \$0.25 a share. The controlling shareholders
spread a (quickly dispelled) rumour that the company has discovered a
cure for death. This causes a surge of demand for the stock. As a
result, when $t\geq{0}$ the price of a share is P(t) dollars, where

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}P(t)=0.25+30t\textrm{e}^{-t/5}.\end{align*}

Here t is measured in days and t = 0 at the instant the rumour starts.
At what time t is the price of the stock increasing most rapidly? Please
justify that the answer you calculate actually gives the greatest rate
of increase.
sols:
\textbf{Step 1: Find objective function}

We have that the stock price is

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}P(t)=0.25+30t\textrm{e}^{-t/5}\end{align*}

and are asked to find when the stock is increasing most rapidly. Notice
we are \textbf{not} asked to find when the price of a stock is a
maximum. This makes sense since if you're looking to buy the stock, you
want it when its value is increasing the fastest. If you buy the stock
at its maximum price then your stock will only lose value as time moves
forward. Therefore the objective function is to maximize the rate of
change, R(t), of the stock price or $\displaystyle {}P'(t)$. We get,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}R(t)=P'(t)=30\textrm{e}^{-t/5}-6t\textrm{e}^{-t/5}=(30-6t)\textrm{e}^{-t/5}.\end{align*}

\textbf{Step 2: Find critical points of the objective function R(t)}

We start by finding critical points of R(t). First take the derivative
of R(t) and set it to zero.

\begin{align*}R'(t)=-6\textrm{e}^{-t/5}-\frac{1}{5}(30-6t)\textrm{e}^{-t/5}=\left(\frac{6}{5}t-12\right)\textrm{e}^{-t/5}=0.\end{align*}

Since the exponential can never be zero we must have that,

\begin{align*}
\left(\frac{6}{5}t-12\right)&=0\\
t&=10.\end{align*}

Thus t=10 is the only critical point of R(t).

\textbf{Step 3: Is the critical point a maximum or a minimum?}

We have still not answered the question, we must still maximize R. We
have that t is in $[0,\infty)$ and so we do not have a full closed
interval to use the extreme value theorem. However, since we only have
one critical point we know that if R(10) is a local maximum then it is
also an absolute maximum and if R(10) is a local minimum then it is also
an absolute minimum.

We will use the first derivative test. Notice, if we pick something
slightly less than 10, then R'(t)\textless{}0 so R(t) is decreasing.
Similarly if we pick something slightly bigger than 10 then
R'(t)\textgreater{}0 so R(t) is increasing. Therefore, by the first
derivative test we conclude that t=10 is a local \textbf{minimum}. Since
it is the only critical point, it is also an absolute minimum.

\textbf{Step 4: Look at the boundaries of the interval of \emph{t} to
find the absolute maximum}

How do we then find the absolute maximum? Even though we do not have a
closed interval for R(t), we can see what happens for large time, i.e.
we can compute

\begin{align*}\lim_{t\to\infty}R(t).\end{align*}

Doing so involves taking an infinite limit of $t\textrm{e}^{-t/5}$. The
exponential decays much faster than the linear term grows so this term
goes to zero. Therefore we have that,

\begin{align*}
&\lim_{t\to\infty}R(t)\\
&=\lim_{t\to\infty}30\textrm{e}^{-t/5}-6\lim_{t\to\infty}6t\textrm{e}^{-t/5}\\
&=0.\end{align*}

Therefore we see that for large time, R(t) goes to zero. We can plug in
the left endpoint,

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}R(0)=(30-6(0))\textrm{e}^{-0/5}=30.\end{align*}

\textbf{Step 5: Conclusion}

Therefore, we see that R starts at 30, decreases to the critical point
at t=10 (note that R(10) \textless{} 0) and then increases towards 0 for
t large. Therefore, R is the biggest when t=0, or right when the rumour
starts spreading. Therefore, the price of the stock is increasing most
rapidly when t=0.
hints:
What is the objective function (the thing you are trying to maximize)?
(Hint: It is not the price of the stock.)

If we find a critical point for the objective function, how can we use
derivative information to conclude if it's a maximum or a minimum? If it
is not a maximum, where else do we look to maximize the objective
function?
